title: Power - two crates pushed with same force

content.question: Two crates are at rest on a flat surface. A student exerts a continuous force of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> on the first crate that causes the crate to accelerate over a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> in time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>. The second crate is accelerated by the same continuous force of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> over the same distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>, but in half the time. The student claims that the same average power is delivered to both crates by the force. Is the claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the force exerted on each crate is the same.
Yes, because the work done on each crate is the same.
No, because the time the force was applied to each crate is different.
No, because the mass of each crate is different.

content.answer: No, because the time the force was applied to each crate is different.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
